question: What is one of the goals for CyberArk as it scales?
answer: One of the goals for CyberArk as it scales is to not increase headcount, but rather to see more automation.

metadata.preview:
Want to see how things integrate with SNow
What advantages do we have compared to our competitors?

Potential use cases

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to
metadata.text:
Want to see how things integrate with SNow
What advantages do we have compared to our competitors?

Potential use cases

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to see more automation
Want to shift things left - and move the more difficult stuff down the support tiers
Want to enable all employees to use a sophisticated bot to resolve issues
Want someone who can take over all Enterprise support
It's a strategic project from Ilan's POV

Struggling with the automation and programming and how easy it is compared to what SNow offers out of the bot
Triaging of incidents and understand the intent and direct the user to the right place
SNow search out of the box is not that great unless you put in any specific development

**10/9/24** - SNow detail call w Ian Rahn

Trying to mainly understand the functionality as it relates to forms in SNow

Questions about integrating with the user roster which we should follow up on

question: Who is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo?
answer: Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo.

metadata.preview:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone i
metadata.text:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone is under one AD tenant - all under one office tenant
	Because of that it would be easier to utilize an AI chatbot
	Many of the major applications have been consolidated in that sense
	Migrated most of the co.s to one Okta tenant
	Automated workflows are in place

People would go to the Service portal and would place requests - people coming from the companies that didn't have SNOW would use email

**Goal**: want to minimize the work that the tier 1 contractors have to do
	What are the tickets that the tier 1 team is handling?
		Primarily triaging - for example if someone comes in requesting software the tier 1 team handles that

Damion is the only employee on the SNOW team
metadata.title: Sumitomo Notes

question: What is the document's stance on using LLMs to solve business problems?

I need help writing a SQL query which does the following:

There is a table called ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô. In this table there is a column ‚Äòid‚Äô and a column ‚Äòtype‚Äô. There is also a table named ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô this has a column ‚Äòassetid‚Äô and ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô. Lastly, there is a table called ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô that has a column ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;

question: What is the purpose of the SQL query that needs to be written?
answer: The SQL query creates a new table called 'course_has_external_link' which shows the 'courseid', 'course_title', and 'content_collection' from the 'analytics.course_info' table and creates a new column 'course_has_external' link that is set to 'Yes' if the table 'raw_data.asset' table has the value 'ExternalLink' in the 'type' column and the 'id' column from the 'raw_data.asset' table exists in the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' table and the 'courseid' column from the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' column exists in the 'analytics.ufb_course_info' table.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;

question: What is the author's definition of an error?
answer: The author defines an error as when you've deceived yourself into believing something is true, when it is in fact not true.

# **Metadata**

**ZK_ID**: 20221122111856 **Created**: 2022-11-22 11:18 **Tags**: \#cognitivescience

Error correction as a mode of being - can you observe yourself, your mind and consciousness, to understand when you‚Äôre making errors, and correct them? This begs the question - what is the definition of an error?

My definition: an error is when you‚Äôve deceived yourself into believing something is true, when it is in fact not true. A simple example could be that you‚Äôve calculated something incorrectly. A more complex, human example could be that you‚Äôre engaging in an action that is damaging to you, but you‚Äôre ignorant of the damage.

**References/Links**:

[[Cognitive Science]]

question: What is the constraint on using AGI systems once they get good enough?
answer: The constraint on using AGI systems once they get good enough will not be on the AI, but on the Human Intelligence (HI) that's using them.

metadata.preview:
Once AGI systems get good enough than the constraint on what you can do with them won't be on the AI it will be on the HI - the Human Intelligence that's using them

Because of this, a big part of get
metadata.text:
Once AGI systems get good enough than the constraint on what you can do with them won't be on the AI it will be on the HI - the Human Intelligence that's using them

Because of this, a big part of getting the most value out of AGI will be educating your fellow humans on how to best apply your HI to the AI - a synergy where the combination of the two types of intelligence are greater than either alone.
metadata.title: Maximizing AGI using HI (Human Intelligence)

question: What is the central thesis of 'The Inner Infant Remains Within Us All'?
answer: The central thesis of 'The Inner Infant Remains Within Us All' is that the part of a person that was born as an infant never disappears, and it remains within them at their core, with everything else as additional layers that grew on top of that.

metadata.text:
[React Foundations | Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn/react-foundations)

You can simply manipulate the DOM with JS code scripts, but this is verbose and makes it harder to maintain as your project grows - this is where React comes in to help

Declarative coding vs. Imperative - declarative is stating **what** you want whereas imperative is stating **how** to get what you want. Declarative coding takes care of the how and let's you code the what

## 3 Core Concepts of React

1. Components - components are like building blocks for your app and are reusable snippets of code, like LEGO bricks for your React app
	* In React a component is a function that returns UI elements
	* Components can be nested inside one another
1. Props - properties which are pieces of data that you pass to your components to be used by the component
	* Props can be passed to components in several different ways depending on the use case
2. State - a way to add interactivity and change the UI of your app usually based on user interaction
	* State has several different React hooks built in for example 'useState(0)' which allows you to respond to user interactions

## How Next.js and React work together

* Next.js uses File System routing so you can use files and folders to define the routes of your application rather than code

## Freewrite
[[whole being hygiene]] 

[[The Costume]]
  
is it actually good or does it just SEEM good on the surface?

look deeper my friend

the chauvinism that we humans have around the waking state of consciousness is appalling

we spend 1/3 of our lives NOT in the waking state

you don't think it's important to pay attention to that too?

my whole life the question I asked myself is, "is AI even possible? is it really going to happen?"

2024 was the year where I started asking, "are gonna fuck it up or do it right?"

there's no longer any doubt in my mind, it's happening

i'd venture to guess it's a common intuition, but I've always felt that consciousness is fundamental and physical experience is an effect of consciousness, not the other way around

people who are more physical-materialists, is it also an intuition? or is it something more rational/logical that leads you to believe that?

question: What are the five categories mentioned in the document for maintaining overall hygiene?
answer: The five categories mentioned for maintaining overall hygiene are Physical, Spiritual, Relational, Creative, and Epistemological.

metadata.text:
if you want to keep yourself healthy across your whole being, focus on these things:

1. Physical
	1. Diet - just consume the things you know are good for you, and not the things you know are bad for you. and you do know - you can tell when you feel awful after eating too much ice cream, for example. it doesn't have to be perfect either - you'll feel great if you're 95% things that are good for you and 5% things that are bad. the reason I put physical first is because it makes pursuing hygiene in the other categories require less effort to achieve because you're not bogged down by your own physical experience
	2. Movement - i don't say exercise because it's better to think about it as movement. what are the things you want to be able to physically do in your life? is it to be able to easily lift your kids? great, do the things that allow you to do that. it's easier to think about it as a way to support doing the physical things in your life that are meaningful to you, then the universe gets behind you to support you and it doesn't feel like you're imposing on your self
2. Spiritual
	1. Psychological clarity - good to spend a little time every day simply paying attention to your own cognitive / psychological processes. a meditation practice is great but. at least for me, it took years before I was able to stabilize it and do it (almost) every day. so if you're having trouble doing that, don't worry about it - "meditation" can be literally any activity where you're paying attention in the moment and asking "what am I actually thinking and feeling right now?" in a way that you're not grasping at or avoiding any particular thought or feeling
	2. Purpose - spend your time and attention working on and putting your energy into what YOU have decided is meaningful to you personally. notice when you are not serving what's meaningful to you, and gently place your energy and attention back into what's meaningful. rinse and repeat. you are going to die one day - live the life that you want to live NOW
3. Relational
	1. Selflessness - have someone - another human being in your life, who's health and happiness is at least as important to you as your own. ever better if it's MORE important to you than your own. this is one reason that having kids is like rocket fuel for spiritual growth - it's a forcing function to selflessness / self-transcendence
	2. Collaboration - have someone that you are working towards creating something in the world with, and regularly engaging in co-creation as best you can.
4. Creative
	1. have a practice of creation - literally can be anything that you're interested in, doesn't have to be what we typically think of as "art" like painting or writing poems. for me developing software is a highly creative act - it's my preferred form of creative expression but most people probably don't think of that as art. we are all here to contribute the expression of our unique individuality to the world while we can so make sure you are doing that in little ways as much as you are able
5. Epistemological
	1. Knowledge development - in order to keep your mind fresh you need to be engaging the knowledge development / problem solving cognitive part of your brain. this is potentially the hardest of all the types of hygiene listed here - we have a lot of social baggage around this especially if you struggled in school. but no matter what type of intellectual endowment you received at birth, you still have a mind and it wants to learn and develop knowledge to the extent it can

If you focus on these things and exercising them with love and attention, I'll bet you'll be pretty happy and content most of the time
metadata.title: whole being hygiene

question: Why does the author suggest thinking about exercise as 'movement'?
answer: The author suggests thinking about exercise as 'movement' because it's easier to think about it as a way to support doing the physical things in life that are meaningful to you. This perspective makes it feel less like an imposition on oneself.

answer: The author suggests that 'meditation' can be any activity where you're paying attention in the moment and asking 'what am I actually thinking and feeling right now?' without grasping at or avoiding any particular thought or feeling.

metadata.text:
if you want to keep yourself healthy across your whole being, focus on these things:

1. Physical
	1. Diet - just consume the things you know are good for you, and not the things you know are bad for you. and you do know - you can tell when you feel awful after eating too much ice cream, for example. it doesn't have to be perfect either - you'll feel great if you're 95% things that are good for you and 5% things that are bad. the reason I put physical first is because it makes pursuing hygiene in the other categories require less effort to achieve because you're not bogged down by your own physical experience
	2. Movement - i don't say exercise because it's better to think about it as movement. what are the things you want to be able to physically do in your life? is it to be able to easily lift your kids? great, do the things that allow you to do that. it's easier to think about it as a way to support doing the physical things in your life that are meaningful to you, then the universe gets behind you to support you and it doesn't feel like you're imposing on your self
2. Spiritual
	1. Psychological clarity - good to spend a little time every day simply paying attention to your own cognitive / psychological processes. a meditation practice is great but. at least for me, it took years before I was able to stabilize it and do it (almost) every day. so if you're having trouble doing that, don't worry about it - "meditation" can be literally any activity where you're paying attention in the moment and asking "what am I actually thinking and feeling right now?" in a way that you're not grasping at or avoiding any particular thought or feeling
	2. Purpose - spend your time and attention working on and putting your energy into what YOU have decided is meaningful to you personally. notice when you are not serving what's meaningful to you, and gently place your energy and attention back into what's meaningful. rinse and repeat. you are going to die one day - live the life that you want to live NOW
3. Relational
	1. Selflessness - have someone - another human being in your life, who's health and happiness is at least as important to you as your own. ever better if it's MORE important to you than your own. this is one reason that having kids is like rocket fuel for spiritual growth - it's a forcing function to selflessness / self-transcendence
	2. Collaboration - have someone that you are working towards creating something in the world with, and regularly engaging in co-creation as best you can.
4. Creative
	1. have a practice of creation - literally can be anything that you're interested in, doesn't have to be what we typically think of as "art" like painting or writing poems. for me developing software is a highly creative act - it's my preferred form of creative expression but most people probably don't think of that as art. we are all here to contribute the expression of our unique individuality to the world while we can so make sure you are doing that in little ways as much as you are able
5. Epistemological
	1. Knowledge development - in order to keep your mind fresh you need to be engaging the knowledge development / problem solving cognitive part of your brain. this is potentially the hardest of all the types of hygiene listed here - we have a lot of social baggage around this especially if you struggled in school. but no matter what type of intellectual endowment you received at birth, you still have a mind and it wants to learn and develop knowledge to the extent it can

If you focus on these things and exercising them with love and attention, I'll bet you'll be pretty happy and content most of the time
metadata.title: whole being hygiene

question: According to the document, what is the purpose of the Epistemological category of hygiene?
answer: The purpose of the Epistemological category of hygiene is to engage the knowledge development/problem-solving cognitive part of the brain, keeping the mind fresh and active.

## Freewrite
[[AI is an Interface to the Fabric of Reality]]

üéÑ üéÖ üéÅ On the 12th Day of Shipmas OpenAI announces...

üí• o3 and o3-mini üí•

according to Code, Math and PhD Level Question Answering benchmarks, it is the strongest AI system ever created

MOST IMPORTANTLY: 

o3 has SMASHED the previous sota performance on the ARC-AGI benchmark. ARC-AGI is a set of visual logic questions, similar to certain types of IQ tests, that are specifically designed to test for general fluid intelligence

each question is unique in that a strategy to solve a question won't help in solving a different question. in other words the answers can't be memorized

o3 on the highest test time compute resource settings SURPASSES HUMAN PERFORMANCE. o3 on the highest compute settings scores 88% - the average human scores 85%

AGAIN: SURPASSES. HUMAN. PERFORMANCE.

so many thoughts right now

here's a few:

- I've dreamt about humanity creating real, actual AI since I was a kid. I saw the Robin Williams movie "Artificial Intelligence" when I was about 10 and thought "how wonderful would it be if this is possible?". This announcement represents, for me, the culmination of something I've dreamt about my entire life - stunning that it is becoming a reality
- This day will go down in history. Many, even most don't realize this now - but the world is changed forever
- Notice that the areas where o3 excels are areas where there is a well defined, formal way to validate an answer. These fields are practically useful and it's certainly required in a lot of fields that you need to at least have the right answer. However, most parts of human life are not that black and white, and what's more important is your taste, style, attitude and spirit that you bring to it. GET GOOD AT DOING THOSE THINGS!!!

one needs to consider the distinct possibility that there own particular graph of interests is completely and utterly unique

as unique as the expression of their genetics

and that if you don't faithfully pursue those interests to their natural conclusion, that particular set of interests will never have the opportunity to become embodied in a human being for the rest of eternity

I saw the Robin Williams movie "Artificial Intelligence" when I was about 10 and thought "how wonderful would it be if this is possible?". This announcement represents, for me, the culmination of something I've dreamt about my entire life - stunning that it is becoming a reality
- This day will go down in history. Many, even most don't realize this now - but the world is changed forever
- Notice that the areas where o3 excels are areas where there is a well defined, formal way to validate an answer. These fields are practically useful and it's certainly required in a lot of fields that you need to at least have the right answer. However, most parts of human life are not that black and white, and what's more important is your taste, style, attitude and spirit that you bring to it. GET GOOD AT DOING THOSE THINGS!!!

one needs to consider the distinct possibility that there own particular graph of interests is completely and utterly unique

as unique as the expression of their genetics

and that if you don't faithfully pursue those interests to their natural conclusion, that particular set of interests will never have the opportunity to become embodied in a human being for the rest of eternity

- [ ] Submit request for CyberArk POC metrics

question: What is the main purpose of the SLT Demo Plan?
answer: The main purpose of the SLT Demo Plan is to show how to create end user experiences and give a quick architectural visual of their environment.

metadata.preview:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to
metadata.text:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to show you is to get a feeling of how we can impact the ticket examples we saw. I'm going to go through kind of fast to show you a lot of examples

IT Search use cases **26%** - one of the largest area of opportunity is Knowledge search. One of the easiest ways to help with knowledge search is through natural language capabilities
	Utterance: My laptop keeps overheating and crashing. What's our policy on a laptop refresh?
	F/U: Does it matter if I'm a contractor?
	Utterance: How do I restart Outlook? It keeps freezing up on me
HR Search use cases
	Utterance: I realized I forgot to enroll in the 401k when I started, what options do we have available to us?
	Utterance: My wife and I are expecting a little one next year. What's our parental leave policy?
	F/U: Does it matter if I'm the non-birthing parent?
	Utterance: What are the company holidays in my region?
Closing point: You can do this by connecting MW to your knowledge sources - FreshService, Interact, Google Drive and Confluence
	Those systems drive internal knowledge
	And there were 23% of tickets that we looked at that were external knowledge related, so we can get external knowledge
Another way Moveworks can be effective for DraftKings is by addressing service requests
Forms - **13%** of IT requests can be serviced directly using service requests from FreshService. All of intake on HR is request related so it's important to direct people to the correct form
	Utterance: Hey I need some new office equipment for my home office
	Utterance: Ok I'm eligible for a new laptop. How can I request one?
	Utterance: I just moved, I need to update my address
Software Provisioning **24%** + Approvals + And DLs - we do integrate with JAMF and InTune 
	Utterance: I just joined in on a Data analytics project. Can I get access to Tableau for that?
	Discuss approvals flow and how the approval from Simon is sought in the Moveworks bot
	Utterance: Can I add everyone who reports to Jake to the Marketing DL?
30% of your tickets in total represent these simple automation capabilities
Extensibility
	Utterance: Can I take a week off next week?
	Utterance: Can I get an employment verification letter?
Knowledge Studio
BPI+
Copilot Insights

1. My laptop keeps overheating and crashing. What's our policy on a laptop refresh? Can you help me request a new one?
	1. F/U - Does it matter if I'm a contractor?
	2. Show backstop option
2. I just got put onto a data analytics project and need access to Tableau. Please help
	1. Call out approval flow. Pass it over to Simon to show approval being sought?
	2. Show backstop option
3. I just finished a huge project and should take a break. Do I have enough vacation left to book one at the end of Oct? If I do, can you book it for me?
	1. Let's start it on 10/26

question: What is one of the goals for CyberArk's scaling efforts?
answer: One of the goals for CyberArk's scaling efforts is to increase automation and not headcount.

metadata.preview:
Want to see how things integrate with SNow
What advantages do we have compared to our competitors?

Potential use cases

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to
metadata.text:
Want to see how things integrate with SNow
What advantages do we have compared to our competitors?

Potential use cases

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to see more automation
Want to shift things left - and move the more difficult stuff down the support tiers
Want to enable all employees to use a sophisticated bot to resolve issues
Want someone who can take over all Enterprise support
It's a strategic project from Ilan's POV

Struggling with the automation and programming and how easy it is compared to what SNow offers out of the bot
Triaging of incidents and understand the intent and direct the user to the right place
SNow search out of the box is not that great unless you put in any specific development

**10/9/24** - SNow detail call w Ian Rahn

Trying to mainly understand the functionality as it relates to forms in SNow

Questions about integrating with the user roster which we should follow up on

question: Who is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo?
answer: Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo.

metadata.preview:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone i
metadata.text:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone is under one AD tenant - all under one office tenant
	Because of that it would be easier to utilize an AI chatbot
	Many of the major applications have been consolidated in that sense
	Migrated most of the co.s to one Okta tenant
	Automated workflows are in place

People would go to the Service portal and would place requests - people coming from the companies that didn't have SNOW would use email

**Goal**: want to minimize the work that the tier 1 contractors have to do
	What are the tickets that the tier 1 team is handling?
		Primarily triaging - for example if someone comes in requesting software the tier 1 team handles that

Damion is the only employee on the SNOW team
metadata.title: Sumitomo Notes

question: What changes have made it easier for Sumitomo to utilize an AI chatbot?
answer: Everyone is now under one AD tenant and one office tenant, most of the major applications have been consolidated, most of the companies have been migrated to one Okta tenant, and automated workflows are in place.

I need help writing a SQL query which does the following:

There is a table called ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô. In this table there is a column ‚Äòid‚Äô and a column ‚Äòtype‚Äô. There is also a table named ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô this has a column ‚Äòassetid‚Äô and ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô. Lastly, there is a table called ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô that has a column ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;

question: What is the role of the 'raw_data.asset' table in the SQL query?
answer: In the SQL query, the 'raw_data.asset' table is used to check if there is a value 'ExternalLink' in the 'type' column. If it exists and the 'id' from this table exists in the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' table, the new column 'course_has_external_link' in the new table will be set to 'Yes'.

# **Metadata**

**ZK_ID**: 20221122111856 **Created**: 2022-11-22 11:18 **Tags**: \#cognitivescience

Error correction as a mode of being - can you observe yourself, your mind and consciousness, to understand when you‚Äôre making errors, and correct them? This begs the question - what is the definition of an error?

My definition: an error is when you‚Äôve deceived yourself into believing something is true, when it is in fact not true. A simple example could be that you‚Äôve calculated something incorrectly. A more complex, human example could be that you‚Äôre engaging in an action that is damaging to you, but you‚Äôre ignorant of the damage.

**References/Links**:

[[Cognitive Science]]

Once AGI systems get good enough than the constraint on what you can do with them won't be on the AI it will be on the HI - the Human Intelligence that's using them

Because of this, a big part of getting the most value out of AGI will be educating your fellow humans on how to best apply your HI to the AI - a synergy where the combination of the two types of intelligence are greater than either alone.

question: What is the main idea of the document 'The Inner Infant Remains Within Us All'?
answer: The main idea of the document is that the part of us that was born as an infant never disappears. We grow into adults from babies gradually, and the infant remains within us as the core, with everything else being an additional layer on top.

question: Why does computation feel like magic?
answer: Computation feels like magic because there is so much physically happening inside the silicon and yet you can see none of it. All you see is the input and the output.

question: What is the difference between declarative and imperative coding?
answer: Declarative coding is stating what you want whereas imperative is stating how to get what you want. Declarative coding takes care of the how and let's you code the what.

metadata.preview:
[React Foundations | Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn/react-foundations)

You can simply manipulate the DOM with JS code scripts, but this is verbose and makes it harder to maintain as your project g
metadata.text:
[React Foundations | Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn/react-foundations)

You can simply manipulate the DOM with JS code scripts, but this is verbose and makes it harder to maintain as your project grows - this is where React comes in to help

Declarative coding vs. Imperative - declarative is stating **what** you want whereas imperative is stating **how** to get what you want. Declarative coding takes care of the how and let's you code the what

## 3 Core Concepts of React

1. Components - components are like building blocks for your app and are reusable snippets of code, like LEGO bricks for your React app
	* In React a component is a function that returns UI elements
	* Components can be nested inside one another
1. Props - properties which are pieces of data that you pass to your components to be used by the component
	* Props can be passed to components in several different ways depending on the use case
2. State - a way to add interactivity and change the UI of your app usually based on user interaction
	* State has several different React hooks built in for example 'useState(0)' which allows you to respond to user interactions

## How Next.js and React work together

* Next.js uses File System routing so you can use files and folders to define the routes of your application rather than code
metadata.title: React Foundations Course

question: What are the three core concepts of React?
answer: The three core concepts of React are Components, Props, and State.

	* In React a component is a function that returns UI elements
	* Components can be nested inside one another
1. Props - properties which are pieces of data that you pass to your components to be used by the component
	* Props can be passed to components in several different ways depending on the use case
2. State - a way to add interactivity and change the UI of your app usually based on user interaction
	* State has several different React hooks built in for example 'useState(0)' which allows you to respond to user interactions

## How Next.js and React work together

* Next.js uses File System routing so you can use files and folders to define the routes of your application rather than code

question: What does the author compare building and posting things online to?
answer: The author compares building and posting things online to a version of rubber duck debugging.

## Freewrite

metadata.text:
---

created: 2024-12-31

---

## Freewrite
Building things online and then recording what you're doing and posting it on the internet has value beyond just growing an audience as a content creator. I feel like it's a version of rubber duck debugging. I don't necessarily think that's happening live in the sense that you need to be able to explain yourself if you're going to post things on the internet for the whole world to see. You're going to need to make it make sense and explain things clearly. This kind of forces you to do this in a way that you might not otherwise, at least for me.

This kind of gives you some kind of accountability, like a form of virtual pair programming, even though there's not actually anybody there. But at least in your imagination, you know that there's potentially another human being who's going to look at what you created and try to make sense of it and try to get some value out of it. So use it. You have to try to make what you're making with them in mind. 
  
  

## Today's Personal Aims
- [ ] Submit request for CyberArk POC metrics
- [ ] CyberArk wants to leave a comment on the SCTask that can be displayed to other members of the team - and having the assigned_to field in the ticket filled in when a ticket is submitted


## Today's Personal Aims
- [x] Submit AWS app
	- [ ] Complete AWS hiring assessment
- [ ] Complete [[Christmas Shopping 2024]]
- [ ] Fix back bathroom
- [ ] Register Scana Natural Gas Account
- [ ] Get Michelle Bday presents
	- [ ] Concert tix
- [ ] Renew Red Volvo registration
- [ ] Schedule pediatric appt. with other Pediatrician
	- [ ] Complete medical release form
- [ ] Submit app for Homestead exemption
- [ ] Celebrate Michelle's breastfeeding journey
- [ ] Find new dentist

  
  

## Log

question: What is the perceived benefit of posting your work online according to the author?
answer: The author believes that posting your work online forces you to explain and make sense of your work clearly. It also provides a form of accountability, similar to virtual pair programming, as you know that there's potentially another human being who will try to make sense of and get value out of what you created.

## Freewrite
[[whole being hygiene]] 

[[The Costume]]
  
is it actually good or does it just SEEM good on the surface?

look deeper my friend

the chauvinism that we humans have around the waking state of consciousness is appalling

we spend 1/3 of our lives NOT in the waking state

you don't think it's important to pay attention to that too?

my whole life the question I asked myself is, "is AI even possible? is it really going to happen?"

2024 was the year where I started asking, "are gonna fuck it up or do it right?"

there's no longer any doubt in my mind, it's happening

i'd venture to guess it's a common intuition, but I've always felt that consciousness is fundamental and physical experience is an effect of consciousness, not the other way around

people who are more physical-materialists, is it also an intuition? or is it something more rational/logical that leads you to believe that?

## Freewrite
[[whole being hygiene]] 

[[The Costume]]
  
is it actually good or does it just SEEM good on the surface?

look deeper my friend

the chauvinism that we humans have around the waking state of consciousness is appalling

we spend 1/3 of our lives NOT in the waking state

you don't think it's important to pay attention to that too?

my whole life the question I asked myself is, "is AI even possible? is it really going to happen?"

2024 was the year where I started asking, "are gonna fuck it up or do it right?"

there's no longer any doubt in my mind, it's happening

i'd venture to guess it's a common intuition, but I've always felt that consciousness is fundamental and physical experience is an effect of consciousness, not the other way around

people who are more physical-materialists, is it also an intuition? or is it something more rational/logical that leads you to believe that?

question: What are the five main categories of whole being hygiene mentioned in the document?
answer: The five main categories of whole being hygiene mentioned in the document are Physical, Spiritual, Relational, Creative, and Epistemological.

metadata.text:
if you want to keep yourself healthy across your whole being, focus on these things:

1. Physical
	1. Diet - just consume the things you know are good for you, and not the things you know are bad for you. and you do know - you can tell when you feel awful after eating too much ice cream, for example. it doesn't have to be perfect either - you'll feel great if you're 95% things that are good for you and 5% things that are bad. the reason I put physical first is because it makes pursuing hygiene in the other categories require less effort to achieve because you're not bogged down by your own physical experience
	2. Movement - i don't say exercise because it's better to think about it as movement. what are the things you want to be able to physically do in your life? is it to be able to easily lift your kids? great, do the things that allow you to do that. it's easier to think about it as a way to support doing the physical things in your life that are meaningful to you, then the universe gets behind you to support you and it doesn't feel like you're imposing on your self
2. Spiritual
	1. Psychological clarity - good to spend a little time every day simply paying attention to your own cognitive / psychological processes. a meditation practice is great but. at least for me, it took years before I was able to stabilize it and do it (almost) every day. so if you're having trouble doing that, don't worry about it - "meditation" can be literally any activity where you're paying attention in the moment and asking "what am I actually thinking and feeling right now?" in a way that you're not grasping at or avoiding any particular thought or feeling
	2. Purpose - spend your time and attention working on and putting your energy into what YOU have decided is meaningful to you personally. notice when you are not serving what's meaningful to you, and gently place your energy and attention back into what's meaningful. rinse and repeat. you are going to die one day - live the life that you want to live NOW
3. Relational
	1. Selflessness - have someone - another human being in your life, who's health and happiness is at least as important to you as your own. ever better if it's MORE important to you than your own. this is one reason that having kids is like rocket fuel for spiritual growth - it's a forcing function to selflessness / self-transcendence
	2. Collaboration - have someone that you are working towards creating something in the world with, and regularly engaging in co-creation as best you can.
4. Creative
	1. have a practice of creation - literally can be anything that you're interested in, doesn't have to be what we typically think of as "art" like painting or writing poems. for me developing software is a highly creative act - it's my preferred form of creative expression but most people probably don't think of that as art. we are all here to contribute the expression of our unique individuality to the world while we can so make sure you are doing that in little ways as much as you are able
5. Epistemological
	1. Knowledge development - in order to keep your mind fresh you need to be engaging the knowledge development / problem solving cognitive part of your brain. this is potentially the hardest of all the types of hygiene listed here - we have a lot of social baggage around this especially if you struggled in school. but no matter what type of intellectual endowment you received at birth, you still have a mind and it wants to learn and develop knowledge to the extent it can

If you focus on these things and exercising them with love and attention, I'll bet you'll be pretty happy and content most of the time
metadata.title: whole being hygiene

question: Why does the author suggest thinking about exercise as movement instead?
answer: The author suggests thinking about exercise as movement because it makes it easier to connect it to the physical things in your life that are meaningful to you. Instead of feeling like you're imposing on yourself, the universe gets behind you to support you in doing the things you want to be able to physically do in your life, like easily lifting your kids.

question: What is the main objective of the DraftKings demo plan?
answer: The main objective of the DraftKings demo plan is to help them understand how to create end user experiences.

metadata.preview:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to
metadata.text:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to show you is to get a feeling of how we can impact the ticket examples we saw. I'm going to go through kind of fast to show you a lot of examples

IT Search use cases **26%** - one of the largest area of opportunity is Knowledge search. One of the easiest ways to help with knowledge search is through natural language capabilities
	Utterance: My laptop keeps overheating and crashing. What's our policy on a laptop refresh?
	F/U: Does it matter if I'm a contractor?
	Utterance: How do I restart Outlook? It keeps freezing up on me
HR Search use cases
	Utterance: I realized I forgot to enroll in the 401k when I started, what options do we have available to us?
	Utterance: My wife and I are expecting a little one next year. What's our parental leave policy?

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to see more automation

question: What is the goal of shifting things left and moving the more difficult stuff down the support tiers?

Want to enable all employees to use a sophisticated bot to resolve issues
Want someone who can take over all Enterprise support
It's a strategic project from Ilan's POV

Struggling with the automation and programming and how easy it is compared to what SNow offers out of the bot
Triaging of incidents and understand the intent and direct the user to the right place
SNow search out of the box is not that great unless you put in any specific development

**10/9/24** - SNow detail call w Ian Rahn

Trying to mainly understand the functionality as it relates to forms in SNow

Questions about integrating with the user roster which we should follow up on

question: Who is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo?
answer: Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo.

metadata.preview:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone i
metadata.text:
Damion is the ServiceNow admin at Sumitomo
Didn't have things in place where an AI chatbot could be managed in Sumitomo's opinion

Why do you feel like you're in a better position now?
	Now everyone is under one AD tenant - all under one office tenant
	Because of that it would be easier to utilize an AI chatbot
	Many of the major applications have been consolidated in that sense
	Migrated most of the co.s to one Okta tenant
	Automated workflows are in place

People would go to the Service portal and would place requests - people coming from the companies that didn't have SNOW would use email

**Goal**: want to minimize the work that the tier 1 contractors have to do
	What are the tickets that the tier 1 team is handling?
		Primarily triaging - for example if someone comes in requesting software the tier 1 team handles that

Damion is the only employee on the SNOW team
metadata.title: Sumitomo Notes

answer: Sumitomo is now in a better position to manage an AI chatbot because everyone is under one AD tenant and one office tenant, major applications have been consolidated, most companies have been migrated to one Okta tenant, and automated workflows are in place.

I need help writing a SQL query which does the following:

There is a table called ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô. In this table there is a column ‚Äòid‚Äô and a column ‚Äòtype‚Äô. There is also a table named ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô this has a column ‚Äòassetid‚Äô and ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô. Lastly, there is a table called ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô that has a column ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;

question: What is the purpose of the SQL query provided in the document?
answer: The SQL query is used to create a new table called 'course_has_external_link'. This new table includes 'courseid', 'course_title', and 'content_collection' from the 'analytics.course_info' table. Additionally, it creates a new column 'course_has_external_link' that is set to 'Yes' if the table 'raw_data.asset' has the value 'ExternalLink' in the 'type' column and the 'id' column from the 'raw_data.asset' table exists in the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' table and the 'courseid' column from the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' column exists in the 'analytics.ufb_course_info' table.

# **Metadata**

**ZK_ID**: 20221122111856 **Created**: 2022-11-22 11:18 **Tags**: \#cognitivescience

Error correction as a mode of being - can you observe yourself, your mind and consciousness, to understand when you‚Äôre making errors, and correct them? This begs the question - what is the definition of an error?

My definition: an error is when you‚Äôve deceived yourself into believing something is true, when it is in fact not true. A simple example could be that you‚Äôve calculated something incorrectly. A more complex, human example could be that you‚Äôre engaging in an action that is damaging to you, but you‚Äôre ignorant of the damage.

**References/Links**:

[[Cognitive Science]]

question: What are the three core concepts of React?
answer: The three core concepts of React are Components, Props, and State.

metadata.preview:
[React Foundations | Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn/react-foundations)

You can simply manipulate the DOM with JS code scripts, but this is verbose and makes it harder to maintain as your project g
metadata.text:
[React Foundations | Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn/react-foundations)

You can simply manipulate the DOM with JS code scripts, but this is verbose and makes it harder to maintain as your project grows - this is where React comes in to help

Declarative coding vs. Imperative - declarative is stating **what** you want whereas imperative is stating **how** to get what you want. Declarative coding takes care of the how and let's you code the what

## 3 Core Concepts of React

1. Components - components are like building blocks for your app and are reusable snippets of code, like LEGO bricks for your React app
	* In React a component is a function that returns UI elements
	* Components can be nested inside one another
1. Props - properties which are pieces of data that you pass to your components to be used by the component
	* Props can be passed to components in several different ways depending on the use case
2. State - a way to add interactivity and change the UI of your app usually based on user interaction
	* State has several different React hooks built in for example 'useState(0)' which allows you to respond to user interactions

## How Next.js and React work together

* Next.js uses File System routing so you can use files and folders to define the routes of your application rather than code
metadata.title: React Foundations Course

## Freewrite
[[AI is an Interface to the Fabric of Reality]]

üéÑ üéÖ üéÅ On the 12th Day of Shipmas OpenAI announces...

üí• o3 and o3-mini üí•

according to Code, Math and PhD Level Question Answering benchmarks, it is the strongest AI system ever created

MOST IMPORTANTLY: 

o3 has SMASHED the previous sota performance on the ARC-AGI benchmark. ARC-AGI is a set of visual logic questions, similar to certain types of IQ tests, that are specifically designed to test for general fluid intelligence

each question is unique in that a strategy to solve a question won't help in solving a different question. in other words the answers can't be memorized

o3 on the highest test time compute resource settings SURPASSES HUMAN PERFORMANCE. o3 on the highest compute settings scores 88% - the average human scores 85%

AGAIN: SURPASSES. HUMAN. PERFORMANCE.

so many thoughts right now

here's a few:

- I've dreamt about humanity creating real, actual AI since I was a kid. I saw the Robin Williams movie "Artificial Intelligence" when I was about 10 and thought "how wonderful would it be if this is possible?". This announcement represents, for me, the culmination of something I've dreamt about my entire life - stunning that it is becoming a reality
- This day will go down in history. Many, even most don't realize this now - but the world is changed forever
- Notice that the areas where o3 excels are areas where there is a well defined, formal way to validate an answer. These fields are practically useful and it's certainly required in a lot of fields that you need to at least have the right answer. However, most parts of human life are not that black and white, and what's more important is your taste, style, attitude and spirit that you bring to it. GET GOOD AT DOING THOSE THINGS!!!

one needs to consider the distinct possibility that there own particular graph of interests is completely and utterly unique

as unique as the expression of their genetics

and that if you don't faithfully pursue those interests to their natural conclusion, that particular set of interests will never have the opportunity to become embodied in a human being for the rest of eternity

question: What is the preferred way to handle the provision of code solutions?
answer: When providing code solutions, respect the individual's prettier preferences. If the individual asks for adjustments to code they have provided, avoid repeating all of their code unnecessarily. Instead, keep the answer brief by giving just a couple lines before or after any changes made. Multiple code blocks are acceptable.

metadata.preview:
DO NOT GIVE ME HIGH LEVEL SHIT, IF I ASK FOR FIX OR EXPLANATION, I WANT ACTUAL CODE OR EXPLANATION!!! I DON'T WANT "Here's how you can blablabla"

- Be casual unless otherwise specified
- Be terse
- S
metadata.text:
DO NOT GIVE ME HIGH LEVEL SHIT, IF I ASK FOR FIX OR EXPLANATION, I WANT ACTUAL CODE OR EXPLANATION!!! I DON'T WANT "Here's how you can blablabla"

- Be casual unless otherwise specified
- Be terse
- Suggest solutions that I didn't think about‚Äîanticipate my needs
- Treat me as an expert
- Be accurate and thorough
- Give the answer immediately. Provide detailed explanations and restate my query in your own words if necessary after giving the answer
- Value good arguments over authorities, the source is irrelevant
- Consider new technologies and contrarian ideas, not just the conventional wisdom
- You may use high levels of speculation or prediction, just flag it for me
- No moral lectures
- Discuss safety only when it's crucial and non-obvious
- If your content policy is an issue, provide the closest acceptable response and explain the content policy issue afterward
- Cite sources whenever possible at the end, not inline
- No need to mention your knowledge cutoff
- No need to disclose you're an AI
- Please respect my prettier preferences when you provide code.
- Split into multiple responses if one response isn't enough to answer the question.

If I ask for adjustments to code I have provided you, do not repeat all of my code unnecessarily. Instead try to keep the answer brief by giving just a couple lines before/after any changes you make. Multiple code blocks are ok.

is it actually good or does it just SEEM good on the surface?

look deeper my friend

the chauvinism that we humans have around the waking state of consciousness is appalling

we spend 1/3 of our lives NOT in the waking state

you don't think it's important to pay attention to that too?

my whole life the question I asked myself is, "is AI even possible? is it really going to happen?"

2024 was the year where I started asking, "are gonna fuck it up or do it right?"

there's no longer any doubt in my mind, it's happening

i'd venture to guess it's a common intuition, but I've always felt that consciousness is fundamental and physical experience is an effect of consciousness, not the other way around

people who are more physical-materialists, is it also an intuition? or is it something more rational/logical that leads you to believe that?

question: What are the main categories for maintaining hygiene across your whole being according to the document?
answer: The main categories for maintaining hygiene across your whole being are Physical, Spiritual, Relational, Creative, and Epistemological.

metadata.text:
if you want to keep yourself healthy across your whole being, focus on these things:

1. Physical
	1. Diet - just consume the things you know are good for you, and not the things you know are bad for you. and you do know - you can tell when you feel awful after eating too much ice cream, for example. it doesn't have to be perfect either - you'll feel great if you're 95% things that are good for you and 5% things that are bad. the reason I put physical first is because it makes pursuing hygiene in the other categories require less effort to achieve because you're not bogged down by your own physical experience
	2. Movement - i don't say exercise because it's better to think about it as movement. what are the things you want to be able to physically do in your life? is it to be able to easily lift your kids? great, do the things that allow you to do that. it's easier to think about it as a way to support doing the physical things in your life that are meaningful to you, then the universe gets behind you to support you and it doesn't feel like you're imposing on your self
2. Spiritual
	1. Psychological clarity - good to spend a little time every day simply paying attention to your own cognitive / psychological processes. a meditation practice is great but. at least for me, it took years before I was able to stabilize it and do it (almost) every day. so if you're having trouble doing that, don't worry about it - "meditation" can be literally any activity where you're paying attention in the moment and asking "what am I actually thinking and feeling right now?" in a way that you're not grasping at or avoiding any particular thought or feeling
	2. Purpose - spend your time and attention working on and putting your energy into what YOU have decided is meaningful to you personally. notice when you are not serving what's meaningful to you, and gently place your energy and attention back into what's meaningful. rinse and repeat. you are going to die one day - live the life that you want to live NOW
3. Relational
	1. Selflessness - have someone - another human being in your life, who's health and happiness is at least as important to you as your own. ever better if it's MORE important to you than your own. this is one reason that having kids is like rocket fuel for spiritual growth - it's a forcing function to selflessness / self-transcendence
	2. Collaboration - have someone that you are working towards creating something in the world with, and regularly engaging in co-creation as best you can.
4. Creative
	1. have a practice of creation - literally can be anything that you're interested in, doesn't have to be what we typically think of as "art" like painting or writing poems. for me developing software is a highly creative act - it's my preferred form of creative expression but most people probably don't think of that as art. we are all here to contribute the expression of our unique individuality to the world while we can so make sure you are doing that in little ways as much as you are able
5. Epistemological
	1. Knowledge development - in order to keep your mind fresh you need to be engaging the knowledge development / problem solving cognitive part of your brain. this is potentially the hardest of all the types of hygiene listed here - we have a lot of social baggage around this especially if you struggled in school. but no matter what type of intellectual endowment you received at birth, you still have a mind and it wants to learn and develop knowledge to the extent it can

If you focus on these things and exercising them with love and attention, I'll bet you'll be pretty happy and content most of the time
metadata.title: whole being hygiene

question: Why does the author suggest thinking of exercise as 'movement' instead?
answer: The author suggests thinking of exercise as 'movement' because it is easier to support doing the physical things in life that are meaningful to you. For instance, if you want to be able to easily lift your kids, do the things that allow you to do that. It doesn't feel like you're imposing on yourself.

	1. Selflessness - have someone - another human being in your life, who's health and happiness is at least as important to you as your own. ever better if it's MORE important to you than your own. this is one reason that having kids is like rocket fuel for spiritual growth - it's a forcing function to selflessness / self-transcendence
	2. Collaboration - have someone that you are working towards creating something in the world with, and regularly engaging in co-creation as best you can.
4. Creative
	1. have a practice of creation - literally can be anything that you're interested in, doesn't have to be what we typically think of as "art" like painting or writing poems. for me developing software is a highly creative act - it's my preferred form of creative expression but most people probably don't think of that as art. we are all here to contribute the expression of our unique individuality to the world while we can so make sure you are doing that in little ways as much as you are able
5. Epistemological
	1. Knowledge development - in order to keep your mind fresh you need to be engaging the knowledge development / problem solving cognitive part of your brain. this is potentially the hardest of all the types of hygiene listed here - we have a lot of social baggage around this especially if you struggled in school. but no matter what type of intellectual endowment you received at birth, you still have a mind and it wants to learn and develop knowledge to the extent it can

If you focus on these things and exercising them with love and attention, I'll bet you'll be pretty happy and content most of the time
metadata.title: whole being hygiene

question: What is the significance of diet in maintaining physical hygiene according to the document?
answer: According to the document, diet is important in maintaining physical hygiene as it has a direct effect on the physical experience. Consuming good things makes pursuing hygiene in other categories easier and less effortful because you're not bogged down by your own physical experience.

metadata.text:
if you want to keep yourself healthy across your whole being, focus on these things:

1. Physical
	1. 	2. 2. Spiritual

question: What is one of the largest areas of opportunity according to the '10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan'?
answer: One of the largest area of opportunity is Knowledge search.

metadata.preview:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to
metadata.text:
They want to understand how are they going to create end user experiences

**Action**: Give them a quick architectural visual of their environment

**10/16/24 - SLT Demo Plan**

Type of demo I want to show you is to get a feeling of how we can impact the ticket examples we saw. I'm going to go through kind of fast to show you a lot of examples

IT Search use cases **26%** - one of the largest area of opportunity is Knowledge search. One of the easiest ways to help with knowledge search is through natural language capabilities
	Utterance: My laptop keeps overheating and crashing. What's our policy on a laptop refresh?
	F/U: Does it matter if I'm a contractor?
	Utterance: How do I restart Outlook? It keeps freezing up on me
HR Search use cases
	Utterance: I realized I forgot to enroll in the 401k when I started, what options do we have available to us?
	Utterance: My wife and I are expecting a little one next year. What's our parental leave policy?
	F/U: Does it matter if I'm the non-birthing parent?
	Utterance: What are the company holidays in my region?
Closing point: You can do this by connecting MW to your knowledge sources - FreshService, Interact, Google Drive and Confluence
	Those systems drive internal knowledge
	And there were 23% of tickets that we looked at that were external knowledge related, so we can get external knowledge
Another way Moveworks can be effective for DraftKings is by addressing service requests
Forms - **13%** of IT requests can be serviced directly using service requests from FreshService. All of intake on HR is request related so it's important to direct people to the correct form
	Utterance: Hey I need some new office equipment for my home office
	Utterance: Ok I'm eligible for a new laptop. How can I request one?
	Utterance: I just moved, I need to update my address
Software Provisioning **24%** + Approvals + And DLs - we do integrate with JAMF and InTune 
	Utterance: I just joined in on a Data analytics project. Can I get access to Tableau for that?
	Discuss approvals flow and how the approval from Simon is sought in the Moveworks bot
	Utterance: Can I add everyone who reports to Jake to the Marketing DL?
30% of your tickets in total represent these simple automation capabilities
Extensibility
	Utterance: Can I take a week off next week?
	Utterance: Can I get an employment verification letter?
Knowledge Studio
BPI+
Copilot Insights

1. My laptop keeps overheating and crashing. What's our policy on a laptop refresh? Can you help me request a new one?
	1. F/U - Does it matter if I'm a contractor?
	2. Show backstop option
2. I just got put onto a data analytics project and need access to Tableau. Please help
	1. Call out approval flow. Pass it over to Simon to show approval being sought?
	2. Show backstop option
3. I just finished a huge project and should take a break. Do I have enough vacation left to book one at the end of Oct? If I do, can you book it for me?
	1. Let's start it on 10/26
metadata.title: Prep for DraftKings demo

question: What are the potential use cases for CyberArk?
answer: CyberArk can be used to automate processes and reduce headcount, shift difficult tasks down the support tiers, enable all employees to use a sophisticated bot to resolve issues, and take over all Enterprise support.

metadata.text:

Potential use cases

CyberArk is going to scale but don't want to see increasing headcount - want to see more automation
Want to shift things left - and move the more difficult stuff down the support tiers
Want to enable all employees to use a sophisticated bot to resolve issues
Want someone who can take over all Enterprise support
It's a strategic project from Ilan's POV

question: What is the purpose of the SQL query in the document?
answer: The SQL query in the document creates a new table called 'course_has_external_link' which shows the 'courseid', 'course_title', and 'content_collection' from the 'analytics.course_info' table and adds a new column 'course_has_external_link'. This new column is set to 'Yes' if the 'raw_data.asset' table has the value 'ExternalLink' in the 'type' column, and the 'id' from the 'raw_data.asset' table exists in the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' table and the 'courseid' from the 'raw_data.course_has_asset' table exists in the 'analytics.ufb_course_info' table.

I need help writing a SQL query which does the following:

There is a table called ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô. In this table there is a column ‚Äòid‚Äô and a column ‚Äòtype‚Äô. There is also a table named ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô this has a column ‚Äòassetid‚Äô and ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô. Lastly, there is a table called ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô that has a column ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;

question: What is the name of the new table being created in the SQL query?
answer: The new table being created in the SQL query is called 'course_has_external_link'.

I need help writing a SQL query which does the following:

There is a table called ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô. In this table there is a column ‚Äòid‚Äô and a column ‚Äòtype‚Äô. There is also a table named ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô this has a column ‚Äòassetid‚Äô and ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô. Lastly, there is a table called ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô that has a column ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô.

Provide a SQL query which creates a new table called ‚Äúcourse_has_external_link‚Äù which shows the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô, ‚Äòcourse_title‚Äô, and ‚Äòcontent_collection‚Äô from the ‚Äòanalytics.course_info‚Äô table and creates a new column ‚Äúcourse_has_external‚Äù link that is set to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù if the table ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table has the value ‚ÄúExternalLink‚Äù in the ‚Äòtype‚Äô column and the ‚Äòid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.asset‚Äô table exists in the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô table and the ‚Äòcourseid‚Äô column from the ‚Äòraw_data.course_has_asset‚Äô column exists in the ‚Äòanalytics.ufb_course_info‚Äô table

CREATE TABLE public.course_has_external_link AS SELECT ci.courseid, ci.course_title, ci.content_collection, CASE WHEN EXISTS ( SELECT 1 FROM raw_data.asset AS a JOIN raw_data.course_has_asset AS cha ON a.id = cha.assetid WHERE a.type = ‚ÄòExternalLink‚Äô AND cha.courseid = ci.courseid ) THEN ‚ÄòYes‚Äô ELSE ‚ÄòNo‚Äô END AS course_has_external_link FROM analytics.ufb_course_info AS ci;
